title: Meet Me in St. Louis (album)
text:
Meet Me In St. Louis is a studio album of <a href="phonograph%20record">phonograph record</a>s by <a href="Judy%20Garland">Judy Garland</a> with <a href="Georgie%20Stoll">Georgie Stoll</a>'s Orchestra, released by <a href="Decca%20Records">Decca Records</a> in <a href="1944%20in%20music">1944</a> featuring songs presented in the <a href="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer</a> <a href="Meet%20Me%20in%20St.%20Louis">eponymous motion picture</a>.
Reception.
Released less than 10 days before <a href="Columbia%20Records">Columbia</a> and <a href="RCA%20Records%23History">Victor Records</a> formally ended the <a href="1942%E2%80%9344%20musicians%27%20strike">1942-44 recording ban</a>, the album peaked at number two on the April 7, 1945 "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" Best-Selling Popular Record Albums chart. In their Record Possibilities column, the magazine praised "<a href="The%20Trolley%20Song">The Trolley Song</a>":
... There's plenty of bounce and the platter is actually given movie treatment, with everything on wax but the kitchen sink... You have to play this three times to take in everything... Even if you have another version get this, too.
"The Trolley Song" <a href="17th%20Academy%20Awards">was nominated for</a> the <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Original%20Song">Academy Award for Best Original Song</a> at the 15th Academy Awards, but lost to "<a href="Swinging%20on%20a%20Star">Swinging on a Star</a>" by <a href="Bing%20Crosby">Bing Crosby</a> from <a href="Paramount%20Pictures">Paramount</a>'s "<a href="Going%20My%20Way">Going My Way</a>". Additionally, the album was the debut of "<a href="Have%20Yourself%20a%20Merry%20Little%20Christmas">Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas</a>", now a perennial holiday standard.
Track listing.
With all selections featuring <a href="Georgie%20Stoll">Georgie Stoll</a>'s Orchestra and Chorus, these newly issued songs were featured on a 3-disc, 78 rpm album set, Decca A-380.
